1a0.text: A farmer grows two types of crops: carrots and peas. They are trying to maximize the crop output of their land.

1a1.text: There are two plots of land the crops can be planted in: one with dark, nutrient-rich soil and another with light, nutrient-sparse soil.

1a2.text: If the dark soil grew only carrots OR peas, then it will produce 8 crates of carrots OR 12 crates of peas.

1a3.text: Likewise, the light soil will produce 5 crates of carrots OR 10 crates of peas.

1a4.text: Of these two plots, which has the [url][color=#E49F5A]absolute advantage[/color][/url] in both crops?
1a4.question: 1a4

1a5.text: If the farmer were to plant only carrots in the light soil, the opportunity to plant peas would be sacrificed. This is known as the [color=#E49F5A]opportunity cost[/color].

1a6.text: As such, the farmer gives up the opportunity to grow 10 crates of peas in exchange for 5 crates of carrots, or 2 crates of peas to obtain 1 crate of carrots (10 / 5 = 2).

1a7.text: Alternatively, the farmer could plant peas, giving up the opportunity to grow 5 crates of carrots in exchange for 10 crates of peas, or 0.5 crates of carrots to obtain 1 crate of peas (5 / 10 = 0.5).

1a8.text: What would be the [color=#E49F5A]opportunity cost[/color] of the dark soil be if the farmer grew carrots in it?
1a8.question: 1a8

1a9.text: And what would be the opportunity cost of the dark soil be if the farmer grew peas in it?
1a9.question: 1a9

1a10.text: The table to the top right has been filled with the opportunity costs of both dark and light soil. When comparing two entites, whichever sacrifices less to obtain one unit of a good has the [color=#E49F5A]comparative advantage[/color].

1a12.text: You have completed 1.a - Output! Select scenario 1.b - Input at the bottom left to continue.

1a11.label: Which of the following statements is true?
content: The dark soil has the absolute and comparative advantage in both crops.
Because the dark soil has the comparative advantage in carrots, the farmer should plant carrots in the dark soil and peas in the light soil.
Because the dark soil has the comparative advantage in peas, the farmer should plant peas in the dark soil and carrots in the light soil.
The farmer should not bother planting crops in the light soil because the dark soil has absolute advantage in both crops.
The farmer should just mix both soils together so they are equal and wouldn't have to be in this situation in the first place.
